Guys this is a cool game.. maybe one of the most original themes I have come across for a video game. I remember seeing trailers for this game as a kid but never ended up playing it until now. I perceive this as a post industrial revolution era masterpiece combined with technological advancement that gives it a touch of steampunk atmosphere. It definitely revealed a niche in the marketplace back in 2013 and it seems to be alive and well in 2021. I should note that this is the only BioShock game I have played but I plan on playing the other ones shortly. The graphics are great for their time as well as the mechanics. I haven't beat the game but obviously I'm loving it so far if I felt obligated to write my first review for a video game here on Steam. The difficultly is pretty low on this game and it's clearly driven by the story and atmosphere which seems like a fair compromise. Overall this game will entertain you even 8 years later (crazy to think it's been that long) . $30 is a bit too much considering how dated the game is: I bought it at $7 just a few days ago during a sale so if you are patient and can wait until another sale, that may be the opportune time. Otherwise, send it and buy it now and have fun! This is a game that just might live with you for years to come....

I played this for the first time in 2016, when it was already 3 years old. I just finished it again as well as all the DLC, and goodness does it hold up well. Gunplay is tight, abilities are cool to use and rewarding, the story is wonderful albeit a bit confusing at times, and the worlds are a sight to look at. Unlike the other two PC ports, this game runs perfectly as well; no crashes or anything of the sort. High FPS at 1080 with everything on ultra settings as well. Get it on sale, or don't, it't worth the cash.

Bioshock Infinite is a game considered to be a masterpiece. I bought this game looking for that masterpiece and came out of the game disappointed and exhausted. The best way to deliver what I'm talking about; is to divide the game into three sections. 
Music, Gameplay, and Story.

Music is probably the strong point of this game. As you walk through Columbia at the beginning it's calming and cheerful string-based instruments. However, you'll notice things get a little uneasy in the music once you start uncovering the truth behind the floating city. You start to get some off notes, maybe some strange off-beat piano keys, just the little things that keep you unnerved. When your in battle the orchestra comes alive in these high-paced symphonies that lead the feelings of the battle. The beautiful thing about the game and the music are those slight glimpses at hope and beauty where it feels as if the world goes still. The music for me in this game is a driving force in continuing it but music isn't what you buy a game for. 

The gameplay is where this starts to trip over itself for me. The game loves to throw new guns and perks at you and for the most part, it's amazing in that sense but after you get to around 3/4 of the game you just stop getting new things. That first half of the game is brilliant with the world and the gameplay but later on, the game just turns into "Here's an area with enemies kill them to progress the story.". The game gets more and more repetitive my favorite thing in the latter half was figuring out the perfect combo of the abilities and weapons to finish the fight faster. Speaking of abilities throughout the game you get these 'tonics drink them and you get new powers. Sounds interesting right? It is! This is the best part about the gameplay other than walking around Columbia is the abilities. There are so many ideas and combinations that keep the gameplay fresh when you unlock these tonics. However, my biggest issue with the game that left me unsatisfied was the story so let us get into that.

The story starts amazing; it's mysterious and engaging. Especially at the time, I was playing this game. When I was playing this game it was during the riots last year when the whole country seemed to be falling apart. This might be why I hold a grudge against this game. Because it reminded me of the outside world too much. During the game, you'll notice racism towards Indians, African Americans, and Homosexuals. In the starting part of the game, there is a fair. One of the games has you shoot the "Vox Populi" which is the minority rebellion. Later on, you'll enter a raffle and win. The prize? Getting a baseball.

The baseball in question is for throwing at two people; A black woman and a white male. The reason why they are tied up is that they were having intimate relations with each other. So either you throw it at the couple or you throw it at the asshole on stage. This game is full of choices like this. Now then what did this game get wrong with the story? To keep this spoiler-free I'll censor the rest. [spoiler]Once you unlock a rift to another dimension the game becomes this confused mutant of itself. You're going through dimensions left and right and eventually, you forget why you even went through the first one. The worst part about this game is when you go without Elizabeth. It is boring. The ending is also unsatisfying and convoluted. [/spoiler] 

It might seem like I dislike this game but I truly don't. I recommend this game actually and I do truly like it. But it's not the masterpiece people search for. It's truly a good experience though. Get in on sale for 10-15 dollars and you won't regret it I'm sure. 7.5/10.

I've read enough Borges to have anticipated the twists and turns of the plot but its the execution that captured me. All the sights and sounds and the gameplay, especially the gameplay, are all superb. And yes, Elizabeth best Serana-level waifu.
10/10 just like when I played it on PS3 many years ago
